awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: RI: Small: Resource-Constrained Multi-hypothesis-aware Perception
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile robots such as self-driving cars, service and household robots, will help people in their daily lives. They operate outside controlled factory environments where they need to perceive the world around them using onboard sensors such as cameras to self-localize, create maps, and perform tasks. Most current perception systems estimate the most likely state of the world but are poor at handling ambiguity and can therefore easily fail. In ambiguous situations, the most likely solution based on the currently available sensor measurements is selected, even though that might not be the one that corresponds to reality. Future measurements can disambiguate the situation, but if the correct solution has previously been discarded, it cannot be recovered, and the robot will fail in its task. This project focuses on developing novel algorithms that can deal with ambiguity for example by keeping track of multiple possible solutions. The key challenge is that the number of possible solutions can grow rapidly, and efficient solutions are needed that can be implemented with the restricted computational resources available onboard mobile robots.

The novel methods to be investigated in this research will extend current state-of-the-art robust perception and belief space planning techniques by approximating the full set of potential hypotheses while simultaneously decreasing computational demands and providing probabilistic bounds on performance. Two different approximations will be investigated: (1) by grouping similar hypotheses into sets that can be approximately evaluated efficiently as a group and (2) by seeking to find a simplified set of hypotheses that is probabilistically close to the original unreduced set of hypotheses. After developing these methods in the passive case, they will be extended to the active perception situation where inherent tradeoffs will be investigated to attain online performance during both simulated and real-world experiments in environments where perceptual aliasing and ambiguity are prevalent.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Enabling Robust Perception in Resource-Constrained Situations

This project focuses on enhancing robotic perception in challenging environments where resources are limited. Traditional methods often assume a single solution to perception problems, but real-world scenarios can present multiple solutions due to ambiguities. Our research explores advanced methods to handle these complexities efficiently, with a particular emphasis on two key contributions: Robust Incremental Inference (riSAM) and Incremental Nonparametric Inference.

Key Contributions

1. Robust Incremental Inference (riSAM)

riSAM is an innovative, open-source algorithm designed to improve real-time perception in robotics by addressing incremental inference, which is crucial for online settings. Traditional methods often struggle with non-convex optimization problems, getting stuck in local minima. riSAM combines incremental inference with a batch graduated non-convexity approach, which helps the algorithm escape local minima as new data becomes available. This is achieved through the introduction of a scale invariant kernel and a custom trust-region optimization technique. These innovations ensure that the algorithm remains robust across different scales of data and can find better solutions without excessive computational cost.

The performance of riSAM has been thoroughly tested, and it consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various scenarios. The algorithm is available as open-source code, allowing other researchers and developers to use and build upon it. Extensive evaluations have been conducted, and the results are being prepared for submission to a journal, ensuring that the scientific community can benefit from these advancements.

2. Incremental Nonparametric Inference

This method provides a novel approach to inference that does not rely on Gaussian assumptions, making it more flexible and efficient for high-dimensional state spaces. Unlike traditional methods that assume a Gaussian distribution, this approach generates samples and reconstructs distributions using kernel density estimators or learning-based procedures. The key innovation here is the use of a slices perspective to approximate joint and marginal posterior distributions directly, avoiding the need for iterative procedures. This method also introduces an early stopping criterion to further reduce computational costs.

The efficiency of this approach is remarkable, achieving improvements in time complexity by up to two orders of magnitude. This makes nonparametric inference feasible for real-time applications, opening up new possibilities for its use in robotics and other fields. The method outperforms existing nonparametric inference algorithms in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

Additional Contributions

Active Multi-Hypothesis SLAM: Based on our prior work on multi-hypothesis inference, we have developed a framework for active SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) that manages multiple possible solutions. This framework actively reduces the number of hypotheses to avoid computational overload while maintaining accuracy. It ensures that the correct hypothesis is not pruned prematurely, maintaining the integrity of the inference process. The effectiveness of this approach has been demonstrated in both simulations and real-world tests.

Tactile Perception: Our research also includes techniques for robots to understand their environment through touch, especially useful in ambiguous situations. We have developed methods for shape and pose estimation using tactile feedback, moving beyond traditional visual methods. This work enhances robot dexterity and spatial awareness, with applications in in-hand manipulation tasks. Our research has been published in leading conferences and journals, contributing to the broader scientific community.

Conclusion

The improved algorithms developed through this project have significant practical applications in indoor mapping and mobile manipulation. By combining vision and touch, robots can better understand and manipulate objects, advancing robot dexterity. Our research has led to several publications and open-source tools, contributing to the broader scientific community and paving the way for more advanced and efficient robotic systems.
